title: Laser printing improves stability of perovskite electronics in extreme environments - Nanowerk
summary:
Laser Printing Enhances Stability of Perovskite Electronics in Extreme Conditions

Date Published: Dec 23, 2024   Source: Nanowerk Spotlight

Researchers have developed a groundbreaking laser printing method that significantly improves the stability of perovskite materials used in electronics, making them suitable for long-term applications in harsh environments such as satellites and medical devices.

  • The traditional perovskite devices degrade quickly under heat, moisture, and radiation.
  • The new laser printing technique eliminates the use of toxic solvents and operates in normal air at room temperature.
  • Studies showed the printed materials retained 90% of their electrical conductivity under extreme conditions, outperforming conventional perovskites.
  • While the electrical conductivity of printed materials is reduced, it remains adequate for practical applications.
  • This advance paves the way for greater commercial adoption of perovskite electronics.
“By creating inherently stable materials through a straightforward printing process, the research establishes a foundation for developing perovskite devices that can operate reliably in real-world conditions.”

This innovative approach not only addresses stability challenges but also opens new avenues for the use of perovskite materials in critical applications where durability is essential.
newTitle: Laser Printing Enhances Stability of Perovskite Electronics in Extreme Conditions

Massive ocean found in deep space - Telangana Today
summary:
Massive Ocean Circling a Quasar Found in Deep Space

Updated On: 23 December 2024, Source: Telangana Today

Astronomers have discovered a colossal water reservoir circling a quasar located over 12 billion light-years away. This notable quasar, APM 08279 5255, encompasses a supermassive black hole and contains water vapour equal to 140 trillion times the volume of Earth’s oceans.

  • The quasar emits more energy than a thousand trillion suns.
  • It is surrounded by hydrogen-rich gases, including water vapour and carbon monoxide.
  • The environment is warm and dense, despite the low gas density, suggesting conditions ripe for star formation.
  • This discovery emphasizes the essential role of water in galaxy and star evolution.
  • It highlights the potential presence of life's ingredients in the early universe.
"This groundbreaking find offers insights into the universe’s formative stages, revealing how galaxies, black holes, and cosmic structures emerged and evolved over billions of years."

The discovery of this massive water reservoir provides significant insights into cosmic evolution, demonstrating how essential water is for the formation and sustenance of celestial structures.
newTitle: Massive Ocean Circling a Quasar Found in Deep Space

title: Astronomers spot binary star system close to Milky Way’s central black hole - News9 LIVE
summary:
A binary star system has been detected in close proximity to Sagittarius A*.

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

An international team of scientists have discovered a binary star system designated as D9, close to the central supermassive black hole of the Milky Way, Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*). The discovery was based on data gathered by the Very Large Telescope (VLT) located in the deserts of Northern Chile.

  • This discovery provides insights on how star systems can survive near supermassive black holes.
  • The binary star system D9 is approximately 2.7 million years old.
  • The two stars in the system are expected to merge into a single star within a million years.
  • Discovery challenges previous beliefs about star formation near black holes.
  • Published findings in Nature Communications highlight the potential for future discoveries of similar systems.
The discovery of D9 demonstrates that some binaries can survive in extreme environments.

The discovery of the D9 binary star system opens new avenues for understanding star formation processes near supermassive black holes.
newTitle: Astronomers Spot Binary Star System Near Milky Way's Central Black Hole

title: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe to make history with unprecedented flyby of the Sun’s corona on Christmas eve D - The Times of India
summary:
NASA’s Parker Solar Probe to Make Historic Flyby of the Sun’s Corona on Christmas Eve 2024

Date: December 24, 2024 Source: Times of India

The Parker Solar Probe is set to make history on December 24, 2024, with a record flyby of the Sun, coming within 3.8 million miles of its surface, and gathering data to understand the extreme temperatures of the Sun’s corona.

  • The flyby will mark the 22nd close approach of the Parker Solar Probe since its launch in 2018.
  • The probe will travel at a speed of 430,000 miles per hour, making it the fastest man-made object ever.
  • Data collected will help resolve the mystery of why the corona is much hotter than the Sun’s surface.
  • The mission aims to improve models of solar behavior, impacting Earth’s space weather.
  • The closest approach is scheduled for 6:53 a.m. EST on December 24, 2024.
“The Parker Solar Probe revolutionizes our understanding of the Sun, providing unprecedented insights into solar activity that affect technology on Earth.”

This flyby will provide crucial data for scientists to comprehend solar phenomena, aiding in the protection of Earth’s technology from solar disruptions.
newTitle: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe to Make Historic Flyby of the Sun’s Corona on Christmas Eve 2024

title: Hubble investigates aftermath of supernova in spiral galaxy - News9 LIVE
summary:
Hubble Investigates Aftermath of Supernova in Spiral Galaxy NGC 337

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

The Hubble Space Telescope has captured NGC 337, a spiral galaxy located 60 million light-years away. A supernova, SN 2014cx, occurred here about ten years ago, significantly enhancing scientific understanding of stellar death and rebirth.

  • The spiral arms of NGC 337 feature contrasting star ages; older stars appear redder while younger stars shine in blue.
  • SN 2014cx was a Type IIP supernova, linked to a massive star that could not sustain its nuclear processes against gravitational collapse.
  • Hubble aims to explore the remnants of the supernova environment, enhancing knowledge of stellar remnants like white dwarfs and black holes.
  • These observations provide insight into how galaxies recycle gas and dust after such catastrophic events.
“Such supernovae take place when a massive star cannot produce enough energy in the nuclear furnace at its core to overcome the crushing pressure of its own gravity.”

This research will continue to inform astronomers about the dynamics of galaxy formation and evolution post-supernova.
newTitle: Hubble Investigates Aftermath of Supernova in Spiral Galaxy NGC 337

Chris Hadfield: The sky is falling – what to do about space junk?

  • Origins of space junk starting with Sputnik.
  • Types of space debris that can fall to Earth.

  • The role of satellite collisions in increasing space junk.
  • Strategies to track and clean up space debris.

ESET's commitment to scientific innovation is reflected in its partnership with Starmus, bringing leading thinkers together to address major global challenges.

This discussion emphasizes the importance of addressing space debris for future space exploration and the vital role of innovation in tackling this growing crisis.

How carbon capture could offset aquaculture emissions - The Fish Site
summary:
How Carbon Capture Could Offset Aquaculture Emissions

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Nature Food

Researchers are investigating an innovative carbon capture model in fish farms that could help to mitigate climate change.

  • A recent study highlights how low-oxygen aquatic environments could capture CO2 efficiently and cost-effectively.
  • The study focuses on using iron sulphide reactions to enhance water alkalinity, increasing carbonate saturation and CO2 absorption.
  • The process captures carbon and reduces hydrogen sulphide concentrations, potentially boosting fish farm productivity.
  • China alone could capture 100 million metric tonnes of CO2 annually with this method.
  • Unlike other methods, this approach offers near-permanent carbon storage for thousands of years.
“Fish farms provide an ideal environment to both reduce carbon emissions and improve fish welfare,” - Mojtaba Fakhraee

This method could be critical in achieving global climate goals and enhancing aquaculture sustainability.

“This is just one potential pathway, but it could significantly improve both carbon capture efforts and the sustainability of the fish farming industry.” - Mojtaba Fakhraee

In conclusion, the integration of carbon capture technology in aquaculture presents a promising solution for climate change mitigation.
newTitle: How Carbon Capture Could Offset Aquaculture Emissions

title: Prof. Rajadurai Chandrasekar elevated to Executive Advisory Board of Journal Small | - UoH Herald
Explained | Why Earth’s magnetic North Pole cruising to Russia and how it affects your GPS - Deccan Herald
summary:
Understanding the Shift of Earth's Magnetic North Pole

Published: 23 December 2024, 09:01 IST

The Earth's magnetic North Pole is shifting from Canada towards Siberia, impacting GPS and navigation systems. This shift is due to the increased activity of the Siberian magnetic lobe.

  • The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) updates the World Magnetic Model (WMM) every five years to account for these shifts.
  • Recent data indicates a significant acceleration in the movement of the magnetic North Pole over the last two decades, especially towards Russia.
  • William Brown from the British Geological Survey noted the pole's unprecedented behavior in recent years.
  • Accurate positioning of the magnetic North is crucial for navigation systems, as minor errors can lead to significant miscalculations in travel paths.
  • The WMM 2025 features improved spatial resolution, enhancing navigational accuracy.
“The current behavior of magnetic north is something that we have never observed before.” - William Brown

The update to the WMM is essential for maintaining precise navigation for various transport systems for the next five years.
newTitle: Understanding the Shift of Earth's Magnetic North Pole

New Study Challenges Dark Energy in Universe's Expansion

Publication Date: October 2023

This article discusses a groundbreaking study that questions the role of dark energy in the expansion of the universe, suggesting that our understanding of cosmology might need a significant revision.

  • The study presents new evidence against the existence of dark energy.
  • Researchers used advanced observational techniques to gather data.
  • Findings could lead to a paradigm shift in theoretical physics.
"If confirmed, these results could change everything we know about the universe's expansion." - Lead Researcher

This research presents significant implications for future studies in cosmology and our understanding of the universe.

Monster black hole in early universe goes into food coma after feasting - News9 LIVE
summary:
Monster Black Hole in Early Universe Goes into Food Coma After Feasting

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

Astronomers have discovered a dormant supermassive black hole in the early universe, formed within 800 million years of the Big Bang. This black hole is about 400 million times the mass of the Sun, challenging existing models of black hole evolution.

  • Discovered using the James Webb Space Telescope.
  • Contains about 40% of the mass of its host galaxy.
  • Growing at a very low rate, about 100 times below its theoretical maximum.
  • Findings challenge conventional models of black hole evolution.
“Even though this black hole is dormant, its enormous size made it possible for us to detect.” - Ignas Juodžbalis

The discovery indicates that the earliest black holes may have grown rapidly and subsequently entered dormancy, suggesting potential new theories in black hole formation.
newTitle: Monster Black Hole in Early Universe Goes into Food Coma After Feasting

YouTuber spends ₹31 lakh to prove Earth is flat. This was the outcome - Hindustan Times
summary:
YouTuber Jeran Campanella renounces Flat Earth theories after a costly trip to Antarctica, discovering Midnight Sun phenomenon contradicts his previous beliefs.

Date: Dec 23, 2024 Source: HT News Desk

Popular 'Flat Earther' Jeran Campanella has changed his perspective on the shape of the Earth after investing nearly ₹31 lakh in a trip to Antarctica, guided by a new phenomenon he encountered there.

  • Campanella initially believed in the Flat Earth theory and aimed to prove it wrong through his trip.
  • Upon arrival in Antarctica, he discovered the Midnight Sun phenomenon, which he thought did not exist.
  • He publicly admitted his previous misconceptions and acknowledged the existence of the 24-hour sun in polar regions.
  • The experiment also challenged claims of restrictions on civilian visits to Antarctica.
"I thought there was no 24-hour Sun. In fact, I was pretty sure of it." - Jeran Campanella

This experience has led Campanella to reconsider significant aspects of his beliefs about the Earth's shape, marking a turning point in his understanding and approach to scientific inquiry.
newTitle: YouTuber Abandons Flat Earth Beliefs After Costly Antarctic Expedition

title: Parker Solar Probe to zoom past 6.1 mn kms from Sun on Christmas eve: NASA By IANS - Investing.com India
Avalanches, icy explosions, shooting geysers: New Year begins on Mars - India Today
summary:
Avalanches, icy explosions, shooting geysers: New Year begins on Mars

Published On: Dec 23, 2024 | Published By: Sibu Kumar Tripathi

The onset of spring on Mars brings dramatic changes, characterized by explosive geological activity as temperatures rise and ice begins to thaw. This time of year is essential for understanding the Martian climate and geological processes.

  • The new year marks the start of spring in Mars' northern hemisphere, leading to significant thawing and geological activity.
  • Spring on Mars is marked by frost avalanches and carbon dioxide gas eruptions from the ground.
  • NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter captures stunning images of these events, shedding light on the planet's evolving landscape.
  • The unique atmospheric conditions on Mars lead to explosive processes, with ice sublimating directly into gas.
“But on Mars, everything happens with a bang,” explained Serina Diniega, a planetary surface scientist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

This explosive activity during Martian spring continues to offer researchers invaluable insights into the planet's past and future, making it a subject of significant interest in planetary science.
newTitle: Avalanches and Explosive Thaw: Mars Welcomes the New Year

Which Continent Is 90% Covered By Ice? - Jagran Josh
summary:
Which Continent Is 90% Covered By Ice?

Date: 23, Dec 2024

Source: jagranjosh.com

Antarctica, the coldest continent on Earth, is covered by ice that constitutes about 90% of its land area, playing a vital role in global climate regulation.

  • Antarctica contains over 90% of its landmass under thick ice.
  • It holds approximately 60% of the world's fresh water.
  • Temperatures in Antarctica can drop below -60°C (-76°F).
  • No permanent human settlements exist; only temporary research stations.
  • Antarctica’s glaciers are critical for global sea levels.
  • Diverse wildlife such as penguins and seals are adapted to the harsh conditions.
  • Home to international research stations studying climate change and other scientific fields.
"Antarctica is crucial for understanding Earth's climate and ecosystems."

This article emphasizes Antarctica's significance in global climate systems and the extreme conditions that define its environment.
newTitle: Which Continent Is 90% Covered By Ice?

title: 5 Unique methods astronauts use to maintain hygiene at International Space Station - India.com
summary:
5 Unique Methods Astronauts Use to Maintain Hygiene at International Space Station

Publication Date: Not specified Source: India.com

Astronauts on the International Space Station (ISS) face unique challenges when it comes to hygiene due to the lack of traditional bathing facilities. Here’s a look at five creative ways astronauts stay clean:

  • For oral hygiene, astronauts use minimal water while brushing their teeth and wipe off excess toothpaste.
  • They wash their hair with no-rinse shampoo, applying it directly and towel-drying without rinsing.
  • Astronauts use no-rinse body wipes instead of baths to clean themselves.
  • They wear disposable clothes that are disposed of after use rather than washed.
  • Routine cleaning of spacecraft surfaces is done with disinfectant wipes and vacuum-like devices to prevent bacteria buildup.
“Astronauts routinely wipe down the spacecraft’s surfaces with disinfectant wipes to prevent bacteria from building up.”

These methods ensure that astronauts maintain personal hygiene effectively while living and working in the confined space of the ISS.
newTitle: 5 Unique Methods Astronauts Use to Maintain Hygiene at International Space Station
